job_title: Student Library Assistant in Lynchburg, VA
pros: Friendly staff and easy shift
cons: There were not really any downsides to this job.

pros: Working in academia is great, and having that opportunity in central Virginia is valuable. Most (maybe all?) full time employees are eligible for tuition remission. It's a pretty well respected institution in the area. There are some active staff affinity groups. Part of the Disciples of Christ church, so has egalitarian values. Pretty nice on campus amenities. The staff senate/staff advisory group is really active, even if everyone isn't involved.
cons: There is no formal onboarding for new employees. Not a diverse environment. A lot of tribalism between departments. Work life balance is kind of luck of the draw depending on what department you work in. The divide between professors and staff is epically vast. High turnover rate it seems, unless you've made it past the 6-8 year mark. The school is in a tight spot with a budget crisis right now, so I question if there are raises/promotions in the near future for newer staff.

pros: Great low-key town to work
cons: Establishment mentality resistant to innovation.

pros: They worked around student schedules
cons: Often very busy without a lot of help

pros: Small community feel Small class sizes
cons: Low salary Low employee morale

pros: Family orientated, great people to work that are understanding, good athletics teams and department.
cons: pay is low, hours are long early mornings and late evenings

job_title: Professor of Accounting in Lynchburg, VA
pros: Feels like a big family.
cons: Lynchburg isn't the most exciting place to live.

pros:
Primed for opportunity and growth as an institution. With significant change occurring in the last 4 years, the institution has begun developing its sense of identity. 

Very young institution if you consider the rebranding that occurred in 2018 from Lynchburg College to the University of Lynchburg. This rebranding has brought in a revitalized spirit.
cons:
Not many young employees, so making a community on campus among employees is a little difficult. Will most definitely have to go out into the community to build a social network of peers your age. 

Can be a little change-resistant, but that is due to the high turnover that the institution has experienced in the last 4 years. University is finally getting to a point where it is stable and they are ensuring the right people are in the right positions.

Student traditions have suffered over the years.

review_title: Fun environment but harsh treatment from supervisor
pros:
Fun Environment
Free Food
Okay Pay
Grill cooks and cashier staff are nice.
cons:
Harsh treatment from Supervisor (If you know you know)
Rushes can be stressful
Understaffed
Expected to cover shifts to make up for understaffed even if you have something important to work on or class. 
Some employees get to call out more than others.

pros: Being a student researcher allowed for immersion and insight into fields that might be relevant to future work--a great opportunity.
cons: Be prepared to spend extensive time working independently, establishing strategies that will improve process of your research.

pros: Great professors, great professors, great professors

review_title: Overall great place for families, support, and flexibility.
pros: People care about and support each other in their best interests - whether those interests are on or off campus.
cons: Those who work inside of the classroom often work long hours and take work home regularly.

pros: Work was very enjoyable.  I worked both during the school year and during the summer setting up for campus events, replacing/fixing/rearranging furniture in student dorms and houses, etc. with a group of fellow student workers.  I loved my coworkers and appreciated having a mix of both indoor and outdoor work.  My supervisors were also very friendly and helped to create a positive work environment.
cons: Nothing that I can think of.  I loved my experience working at University of Lynchburg.

review_title: The ups and downs of being a "family"
pros:
-great benefits
-good amount of respect for time off needed for family illness, etc
-very caring community
-jobs are fairly stable and secure
cons:
-"family" atmosphere is used to explain unprofessional approaches
-loyalty is rewarded over performance
-upper management is sometimes blind to the needs of the "common worker"
-wide disparity across different departments

review_title: Great university and place to work!
pros: I worked in many different roles at LC, and I enjoyed all of them. The people there are great to student workers and there are lots of opportunities.
cons: I think the pay is one downside, because it's typically minimum wage. You're also only allowed to work one job now, which is frustrating for future student workers.

pros: The campus is very pretty and well designed. The city of Lynchburg is just large enough to provide basic amenities while avoiding the pains of big-city life.
cons: Too many of the students are obnoxious East Coast students who couldn't get into more prestigious universities, so settle on LC. The teaching load is high and the support for research is mediocre at best.

review_title: run. run, for the seven hills.
pros: accommodating to students
cons:
they really push the family metaphor, but it's not true.  
culture and morale has been on the downswing for a while. 
loyalty is rewarded over performance
most of the people work there because they have nowhere else to go. 
leadership is out of touch with the realities of today's workforce and very they (the administration) is unpredictable.

pros:
-Fantastic leadership in direct-supervision position
-Strategic advancement pyramid 
-Fosters development within roles and encouragement all around
-Positive environment 
- Some leniency in work depending on department
cons:
-Often the bureaucracy can hinder growth or development of programs
- LC Initiative groups often cross over with already existing programs
- Limited student working hours

pros: College cares about it's employees
cons: Hours are terrible with not much chance to advance (unless a buddy gets appointed as a supervisor)
